docs.lead_paragraph: BEFORE heading off to college, students go through the rituals of packing, buying books and supplies and checking class schedules and living arrangements. Often low on the priority list -- if it's there at all -- is reviewing health insurance coverage. Sure, college students are generally young and healthy, and many are already covered by employer-sponsored health plans, usually through their parents. But those plans are not foolproof: some cover non-emergency expenses only if the school is within the plan's geographic area, while many others apply only to full-time students, and only until they are 23. Some policies may also require referrals for certain services or when patients go out of their network of physicians.

headline.main: Personal Business; In Loco Parentis Doesn't Necessarily Pay the Doctor

docs.abstract: Many college students have health insurance coverage through employer-sponsored health plans, usually their parents', but that coverage can be spotty; health care experts say that in some case, students may be better off with their own policies, like those sponsored by schools themselves or offered by private insurers; photo (L)
docs.snippet: BEFORE heading off to college, students go through the rituals of packing, buying books and supplies and checking class schedules and living arrangements. Often low on the priority list -- if it's there at all -- is reviewing health insurance...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As I was reading Bob Herbert's Aug. 7 column, ''Despair of the Jobless,'' I was reminded how far I have fallen from the ranks of the Americans who are getting ahead. Three years ago (when Bill Clinton was president) my life was great. I was making $100,000-plus a year in a job with great benefits, and my financial -- and personal -- future looked rosy.
docs.abstract: Gary Voudrie letter on grim picture for unemployed people like himself (Aug 7 Bob Herbert column); blames Pres Bush's 'voodoo economics'

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts had just finished a walking tour through Littleton, a small town near here in the White Mountains, when he paused to take questions from local reporters outside a candy store. There was one subject this day: Howard Dean. Again and again, Mr. Kerry was asked his views of Dr. Dean. Again and again, Mr. Kerry, who had passed a half-dozen Dean placards on his walk, demurred. When a television reporter taunted Mr. Kerry to at least utter Dr. Dean's name, Mr. Kerry, who is rarely at a loss for words, grinned and pinched his mouth shut.

headline.main: As Campaign Tightens, Kerry Sharpens Message

docs.abstract: Sen John Kerry of Massachusetts is sharpening message of his campaign for Democratic presidential nomination, once described as themeless and toothless, to meet challenge of Howard Dean's onrushing campaign; now accuses corporate chieftains of 'looting America' and says Pres Bush is presiding over worst American economy since Great Depression; questions Bush's credibility and competence on issues as different as tax cuts and postwar cleanup of Iraq; stands by his vote for war in Iraq, where before he was accused of vacillating on issue; seeks to claim mantle for expanded health care coverage; has begun his own campaign Web log modeled after Dean's; invokes his stature as Vietnam veteran as he challenges stature of his Democratic opponents to withstand debate with Bush on national security; photo with Dean (M)
docs.snippet: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts had just finished a walking tour through Littleton, a small town near here in the White Mountains, when he paused to take questions from local reporters outside a candy store. There was one subject this day: Howard...

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE'S little question that the traditional concept of retirement -- a k a being on vacation for the rest of your life -- is rapidly changing to reflect the more proactive mind-set of the baby boomers, as well as the economic realities of shrinking pensions and paltry savings. Tomorrow's retirees are going to be anything but on a permanent holiday, and two recent books aim to provide some emotional and psychological guidance for a time of life that for many may become known as a postwork career.
docs.abstract: Fred Brock reviews two new books on retirement: Too Young to Retire: An Off-the-Road Map to the Rest of Your Life, by Marika and Howard Stone, and Second Acts: Creating the Life You Really Want, Building the Career You Truly Deserve, by Stephen M Pollan adn Mark Levine; photo (M)
docs.snippet: THERE'S little question that the traditional concept of retirement -- a k a being on vacation for the rest of your life -- is rapidly changing to reflect the more proactive mind-set of the baby boomers, as well as the economic realities of shrinking...

docs.lead_paragraph: SOMETIME soon, the House and the Senate may agree on a bill that will add prescription drug coverage to the federal Medicare program, which provides health insurance to 40 million elderly and disabled Americans, including more than 200,000 in Nassau County. Adding such benefits to Medicare is an important step toward improving health care for all Americans.But regardless of the final form of the legislation that emerges from the Senate and House conference -- if, indeed, anything emerges -- two things are clear. First, there will be no new assistance for the uninsured, non-disabled population under 65, a group that includes more than 260,000 people in Nassau alone. Second, large gaps in prescription drug coverage for Medicare beneficiaries will remain, for which they will be financially responsible.
docs.abstract: Howard Weitzman Soapbox essay on proposed legislation to add prescription drug coverage to federal Medicare program; supports plans for private pharmacy discount cards (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: STUDENT health centers vary considerably in the range of services they provide, often depending on the size of the school. But the centers generally provide good care, health care experts say. About 10 percent of the centers are accredited by one of two organizations, the Accreditation Association for Ambulatory Health Care (www.aaahc.org), or the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations (www.jcaho.org).

headline.main: Personal Business; Comparing the Campus Health Centers

docs.lead_paragraph: Staci Jana Gershuny, the daughter of Keri and Leonard Gershuny of New Hempstead, N.Y., is to be married today to Doron Emanuel Zeif, the son of Susan and Robert Zeif of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Aaron Slonim is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Keter Torah in Teaneck, N.J. The bride, 23, is the fund-raising associate at the Jewish Community Center on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She graduated from Brandeis. Her father works in Ridgefield Park, N.J., as the inventory controller for the United States unit of the Agfa-Gevaert Group, the Belgian manufacturer of film, film processing and health-care and industrial imaging products. Her mother is the director of the life and health underwriting department at the Bertholon-Rowland Corporation, an insurance brokerage in Manhattan.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Five Fat Sensitive Men were pushing themselves, trying to beat the Lightweights and Johnny Craig, who were tied for first. But then Gone in 60 Days came up from behind, leaving everyone in the dust. This was not a horse race. It was just another week at VSM Abrasives, a maker of industrial sandpaper in O'Fallon, Mo. In the spring of 2002, to motivate employees to slim down and thereby help reduce health insurance costs, VSM started its Get Healthy for Life contest.

headline.main: Executive Life; Shed Some Pounds (and Get a Bonus)

docs.abstract: Companies are addressing problem of obesity among employees, sponsoring exercise and diet programs, hiring counselors and making cafeterias more conducive to weight control; weight-loss competitions are popular at some companies; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: John Kerry is recognized in the Senate more for his expertise on foreign policy and for mounting Congressional inquiries than he is for steering legislation into law. A look at his record since joining the Senate in 1985 reveals modest legislative success, although he has not been a central player in domestic policy fights over taxes, spending and health care.

headline.main: A Record Built on World Affairs and Inquiries, Not Bills

docs.abstract: Sen John Kerry is recognized in Senate more for his expertise on foreign policy and for mounting Congressional inquiries than he is for steering legislation into law; some say his Massachusetts colleague, Sen Edward M Kennedy, has unintentionally limited Kerry's legislative influence (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tenet Healthcare, already the subject of multiple government inquiries, said yesterday that it was under investigation by Florida for Medicaid fraud. State officials issued a subpoena June 6 requesting employee records and doctor contracts at Florida hospitals from 1992 to the present, Tenet said in a regulatory filing. The records include loan, purchase and sale agreements, Tenet said.

headline.main: Tenet Healthcare Says It Faces Florida Medicaid Investigation
